topic_description: Temporary endeavor with beginning and end. Project creates unique product, service and result.
Program is a group of related projects.
Portfolio is a group of programs, individual projects and related operation and it achieves specific strategic goal.
It serves as a guide or driver for the project, program and portfolio management. OPM3 designed to help organizations determine their level of maturity in project management.
1. Supportive: Low level control over project  2. Controlling: Moderate level control over project  3. Directive: High level control over project
Time, Cost, Scope, Quality, Customer Satisfaction, Risk, Resources.
1. Projectized Organization 2. Functional Organization
Lessons Learned is completed by stakeholder
Nothing to do with matrix organization.  It mentions project team collocated or located in the same room.
Processes, Procedure, Policies, Corporate knowledge base, Historical information and Lesson learned.
Company culture, existing system, organization structure and hierarchy.
Act as a staff assistant and communication coordinator. He can’t make or impose decision.
He has an authority to make the decision and report to higher level managers.
It means what you need to do to perform work.
What you need to do to manage the work (5 Project Management Processes) Initiating, Planning, Executing, Monitoring and Controlling, Closing.
Weak Matrix, Strong Matrix, Balance Matrix
Project selection is part of an organization’s portfolio management process.
1. Change Management Plan  2. Configuration Management Plan  3. Requirements Management Plan  4. Process Improvement management plan
Project management system to authorize start of work package or activity.
Evaluate impact, identify options, get change requirements approval internally, get customer buy in.
It means changes related to standardize forms, reports, processes, procedure.
It means changes related to scope.

Projects are chartered to give the project manager the authority to act on behalf of the project sponsor or customer.
Projects are chartered to solve a problem or seize an opportunity.
Project selection is part of an organization’s portfolio management process.
1. Benefit measurement  2. Murder board  3. Peer review  4. Scoring model  4. Economic models
1.  Net Present Value (NPV) 2. Internal Rate of Return (IRR) 3. Payback Period 4. Cost Benefit Analysis
Length of a time for an organization to recover its investment before it starts accumulating profit.
SOW created by customer or sponsor.
It is also known as weighted scoring models. It uses a common set of values to “score” each project’s worthiness.
This model compares benefits to costs.  Consider a BCR of 4:1 versus another project of 2:5.
How much is the Present value (PV) worth in the future?
How much will a future value be worth in today’s dollars?
Rate at which project inflows and outflows are equal
An NPV greater than one is good, less than one is bad.
Complex formulas to determine a project’s worthiness to be selected;   1. Linear programming  2. Non-linear programming  3. Integer algorithms  4. Dynamic programming 5. Multi-objective programming
Requirements related to product of the project.  It can also define as product deliverables with their associated features and functions.
Work project will do to deliver product it encompasses product scope, management activities (meeting/report), planning, and coordination.
It helps to link the requirement to the objective and /or requirements to ensure strategic goals are accomplished.
Scope Statement = (project scope + product scope + deliverables + acceptance criteria + what is not part of the project + Assumption and constraints).
Changes related to standardize forms, reports, processes, and procedure.
Changes related to scope.

Project team creates WBS. WBS does NOT show dependences. The WBS is a deliverables-oriented decomposition of the project scope.  Some activities are allowed in the WBS (for example, testing). The WBS can be based on a previous project and this is called a WBS template, also written as WBT.

It is an accounting system to track project costs by category (labor, specific materials, and contractor rates).  A project’s chart of accounts works with the organization’s chart of accounts for specific deliverables, work, and/or materials.
It comprised of the project scope statement, the WBS, and the WBS Dictionary. Project team creates scope baseline.
It is a numbering system to identify the deliverables down to the work package within a WBS.
Description of work to be done for each work package. The WBS dictionary defines all of the project deliverables, resources, cost and time estimates, and associated information for each work package.
Waiting time between activities (positive time)
Activities are moved closer together or even overlap (negative time)
It means adding resources to reduce the project duration.  This adds costs to the project.
It allows project phases to overlap to reduce the project duration.  This adds risk to the project.
The amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the next activity’s start date.
The amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project’s end date.
An opportunity to delay an activity.  It also called slack.
This relationship means Task A must complete before Task B can begin.  This is the most common relationship.
This relationship means Task A must start before task B can start.  This relationship allows both activities to happen in tandem.
This relationship is unusual and is rarely used.  It requires Task A to start so that Task B may finish.  It is also known as just-in-time (JIT) scheduling.

This time estimate approach used three factors to predict the duration of each task.  The formula is (optimistic + most likely + pessimistic) divided by three.  It is an average of the three time factors for each activity.

This approach is weighted on the most likely estimate.  The formula is the optimistic, plus four times the most likely, plus the pessimistic; this sum is then divided by six.  I like to write this as (O + (4ML) + P)/6.

This network diagramming approach is based on the availability of project resources to determine project completion.  It is more accurate than the traditional network diagram, but is more complex to create.

The Early Start (ES) of the first task is one. The Early Finish (EF) is a task’s ES, plus the duration, minus one. The ES of the next task(s) will be the EF for the previous activity, plus one. The EF for the next task(s) equals its ES, plus the task duration, minus one. Use caution with predecessor activities; the EF with the largest value is carried forward.

Backward pass starts at the end of the project network diagram.  The Late Finish (LF) for the last activity in the project network diagram equals its EF value.  The Late Start (LS) is calculated by subtracting the duration of the activity from its LF, plus one. The next predecessor activity’s LF equals the LS of the successor activity minus one. The LS is again calculated by subtracting the task’s duration from the task’s LF, plus one.
The cost of the deliverable, service, or materials can fluctuate based on varying factors.
It is a constant “fixed” cost throughout the project.
An expense that can be shared with other projects or the organization, such as rent, phone, or equipment.
Costs that are directly tied to the project.

Sunk Costs are monies that have been invested into a project.  Sunk costs are gone; they are “sunk” into a project. Cost that has incurred and it can’t be recovered. Sunk cost should not be consider when deciding whether to continue with trouble project or not.

An Opportunity Cost is the amount of an opportunity that is given up. Consider, project A is worth $55,000 and project B is worth $89,000, you’d choose project B to do.  The opportunity is $55,000 – the amount of project ‘A’ that you can’t do because of the opportunity of project ‘B’.
Rough Order of Magnitude: Simple, early estimate.  Range of variance is -25% to +75% for the project completion.
Early planning estimate and / or top-down approach.  Range of variance is -10% to +25% for the project completion.
Most accurate estimate, but takes longest to complete; uses the bottom-up approach.  Range of variance is -5% to +10% for the project completion.
Requires a WBS and accounts for each work package chart of accounts.
Creates an analogy between projects; also known as a top-down estimate.
Uses a parameter (cost per ton, cost per unit) for the estimate.

1. Always start with earned value  2. Variance means subtraction  3. Indexes are “something” divided by “something” and they show performance for the project objectives.  4. However, when it comes to any index, the closer to 1 the better  5. Variances can be positive or negative
Heuristic is rule of thumb example cost per line of code, cost / sq. foot
FMEA: Failure mode and effect analysis (Find the details in Quality chapter)
BAC = Total Budget, Budget at Completion
Cost of quality is the cost to achieve the expected quality on a project. Considering a cost of training, safety, and materials (It is part of the Cost of Quality)

Cost of poor quality, also known as the cost of nonconformance to quality, is the cost of not achieving quality: re-work loss of life or limb, loss of sales. Don’t change your answers.  Most people change correct answers to wrong answers.
80-20 Rule relate how small you breakdown work packages in work breakdown structure Arbitrator is skilled third party
Consensus management is always related to time because it takes time to make decision as you have to take everyone’s opinion.
Quality: degree to which project fulfills requirements
1. Joseph Turan invented 80/20 principle  2. W Edwards Deming: 14pt Quality Management (Plan-Do-Check-Act)  3. Philip Crosby: Concept of cost of poor quality and zero defect
Benefit or revenue to be received from improving quality equals incremental cost to achieve that quality.
Supplier delivers raw material when needed.
Project Manager is not spending too much to achieve particular level of quality.
Increased cost, decreased profit, low morale, low customer satisfaction, increased risk, Rework, and schedule delays
1. Helps focus attention on most critical issue.  2. Prioritize potential causes of the problems.  3. Separate critical few from uncritical many.
Tracks 2 variables to determine their relationship.
Sample size and frequency of measurement are determined as plan a management process. Actual sampling is done in control quality.

topic_name: Herzberg’s Theory of Motivation - Hygiene Agents
Herzberg’s Theory of Motivation - Motivating agents

topic_description: An offer and consideration contracts are backed by the court system.
Risk is with the buyer as the buyer pays for cost of overruns.
Risk is with the seller as seller pays for cost overruns.  Detail specification knows what to do.
Buyer pays for the time and materials of the vendor. It must have a not-to-exceed (NTE) clause.
A unilateral form of a contract.
The buyer tells the vendor they intend to do business with them, not a binding agreement.
Generally short-term purchase used as a stopgap or emergency response.
Vendors all meet with the buyer to discuss the details of the statement of work so they may prepare a bid, quote, or proposal.

The buyer creates a statement of work (SOW) with an invitation for bid (IFB), request for quote (RFQ), or request for proposal (RFP) for the vendors.  (IFBs and RFQs both want just a price; a proposal wants ideas)

A bidder conference allows sellers to ask questions about the SOW.  The buyer may create an updated SOW to give back to the sellers that attended the bidder conference. Sellers respond with a bid, quote or proposal. The buyer completes seller selection and creates a contract.
Decentralized contracting is done by the PM; centralized contracting is done with a purchasing agent or through a central procurement office.

This is a three-step process of identifying the project stakeholders early in the project, identify the impact/support of each stakeholder, and then plan how to influence stakeholders to act in given situations.
Documents stakeholder identification, assessment of influence, and stakeholder type.
These are grids to plot out stakeholder power, influence and interest in the project.
How much power/interest do the stakeholders have?
How much power / influence do the stakeholder have?
How much influence (involvement of decisions) and impact on project change do the stakeholders have?
Classifies stakeholders based on power, urgency, and legitimacy for the project.

Make decision based on best intestate of the company rather than your own. Only accept assignment you are qualified to complete protect proprietary information. Report unethical behavior and violations

Maintain attitude of mutual co-operation, Respect cultural difference. Engage in good faith Negotiations. Be direct dealing with conflicts. Do not use your power or position to influence other for your benefits.
Act impartially without bribery, continuously looking for conflict of interest and disclose them. Do not discriminate against others; do not use your position for personal or business gain.
Try to understand the truth. Be truthful in all communication and create that environment.
